dataset.title: OVERVIEW OF SEED DORMANCY IN VIBURNUM (CAPRIFOLIACEAE)

creator.organizationName: Department of Biology, University of Kentucky
Division of Silviculture, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute
Division of Silviculture, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute
Department of Biology, University of Kentucky

abstract.para: Many species of Viburnum are cultivated ornamentals, but their propagation from seeds may require many months. This overview provides a better understanding of why germination may take so long. Seeds have a linear underdeveloped embryo which must grow inside the seed before the root emerges. In addition, the embryo has physiological dormancy (PD); thus, seeds have morphophysiological dormancy (MPD). In most species of Viburnum, there is a period of several weeks or months between root and shoot emergence, and this kind of dormancy is described as deep simple epicotyl MPD. Warm stratification (summer) is required to break part of the PD, after which the embryo grows and the root emerges (autumn). Then, the seed with the developing root must be cold-stratified to break the remaining PD in the shoot, which emerges in spring. An analysis of the dormancy-breaking and germination requirements of seeds with deep simple epicotyl MPD reveals that only the shoot has this level of MPD; the root has nondeep simple MPD and thus requires only warm stratification to break the PD and promote growth of the embryo. In at least a few species of Viburnum, the shoot has only nondeep simple MPD, and dormancy in seeds of these species is described as nondeep simple epicotyl MPD. We discuss use of the “move-along” experiment to help define the seed dormancy-breaking and germination requirements of a species and present data for V. formosanum, which has nondeep simple epicotyl MPD. Clearly, if cold stratification is given first, in this and other species of Viburnum, i.e., seeds are sown in early winter, germination is delayed because breaking of the first part of PD (by warm stratification) cannot occur until summer.

intellectualRights.para: If you want to use the information, please contact with me.

section.title: CLASSES OF SEED DORMANCY
section.para: As a background for our discussion of seed dormancy
in Viburnum, the reader needs to be familiar
with the classes of dormancy, especially physiological
dormancy and morphophysiological dormancy. Thus,
we will briefly describe the five classes of dormancy
here, using information from Nikolaeva (1969, 1977)
and Baskin and Baskin (1998, 2004, 2008).

section.title: VIBURNUM AS A SLOW-TO-GERMINATE ORNAMENTAL
section.para: According to Mabberley (1997), there are 150 species
of Viburnum (Caprifoliaceae), and these shrubs
or small trees are native to temperate and warm areas,
especially Asia and North America. However, species
of Viburnum also occur in Central and South America
and Indonesia (Ferguson 1966). Various members of
this genus are cultivated for their fragrant flowers andattractive fruits and/or leaves (Floyd et al. 1980, Coats
1992). The dispersal unit is a drupe, and soon after
dispersal the soft exocarp and mesocarp decay, leaving
the firm, but water-permeable, endocarp around the true
seed (Hidayati et al. 2005). In this paper, “seed” means
the true seed surrounded by the endocarp.

section.title: CLASS OF DORMANCY IN VIBURNUM SEEDS
section.para: The embryo in seeds of various Viburnum species,
including V. acerifolium (Giersbach 1937), V. dentatum
(Martin 1946), V. digitatum (Numata and Asano 1970),
V. formosanum (Baskin et al., unpubl.), V. lentago
(Young and Young 1992), V. odoratissimum (Baskin et
al. 2008, unpubl.), and V. opulus (Watson and Dallwitz
1992 and onward) is described as linear -underdeveloped.
That is, the embryo in freshly-matured seeds is
longer than wide, but its length increases greatly within
the seed, i.e., prior to the time of root emergence. Examples
of the increase in embryo length prior to root
emergence are: V. acerifolium, 294% (Hidayati et al.
2005); V. arboricum, 196%; V. betulifolium, 547%; V.
foetidum, 416%; V. formosanum, 375%; V. luzonicum,
339% (Baskin et al. unpubl.); V. odoratissimum, 300%
(Baskin et al. 2008); and V. tinus, 725% (Karlsson et

section.title: LEVELs OF MORPHOPHYSIOLOGICAL DORMANCY
section.para: Depending on the warm and/or cold stratification
requirements to break PD, temperature requirements
for embryo growth (i.e., grow at warm- vs. low coldstratifying
temperatures), and response of seeds to GA3,
nine levels of MPD have been distinguished (Nikolaeva
1969, 1977, Baskin and Baskin 1990, Baskin et al.
2008). The nine levels of MPD are: nondeep simple,
intermediate simple, deep simple, deep simple epicotyl,
nondeep simple epicotyl, deep double, nondeep complex,
intermediate complex, and deep complex.

section.title: GERMINATING VIBURNUM SEEDS
section.para: In some species of Viburnum, e.g., V. acerifolium
(Hidayati et al. 2005), the high temperature (25/15°C)
that promotes the breaking of the first part of PD also is
favorable for embryo growth and root emergence. Thus,
if seeds are maintained on a moist substrate at 25/15°C
for about 30 weeks a high percentage of the seeds will
have a root growing into the substrate. In many species
of Viburnum, however, production of roots is very
slow, if it occurs at all, until seeds are moved from ahigh (e.g., 25/15, 30/15°C) to a relatively cool (20/10,
15/6°C) temperature. The relatively cool temperature
is required to promote embryo growth, after which the
root emerges from the seed. After the warm-stratification
treatment has been completed, how does one know
if the species under investigation has seeds that need
to be moved to a relatively cool temperature for a high
percentage of the seeds to produce a root? One way to
answer this question, is to do a “move-along” experiment
(Baskin and Baskin 2003).

dataTable.entityName: Fig. 1. Percent (mean ± SE, if ≥ 5%; n = 3 replicates of 50 seeds each) root emergence from Viburnum formosanum seeds collected in Taiwan
